BPS Plus will take place weekly ‚Äì Monday/Wednesday OR Tuesday/Thursday; 4 sessions total from 4:30 p.m.‚Äì 6:00 p.m. 9/14/20-9/24/20

post_text: The Berkshire PE Team has been selected as one of the top 5 Middle Schools in the Country and is competing for the title of American Heart Challenge Volunteer Coordinators of the Year! column1: The Welcome Kits can be purchased here: https://supportbef.ejoinme.org/kindergarten"
image:
Birmingham Education Foundation
July 30 at 5:56 PM ¬∑

Calling all incoming BPS kindergarten families - we want to help you celebrate your new student with our Kindergarten Welcome Kits! For $25, you will receive a t-shirt that says either Groves or Seaholm, Class of 2033, a fun yard sign, and a packet of information to help you get to know your new school. Kits will be delivered to porches just before school begins on August 31.

Purchase your kit here: https://supportbef.ejoinme.org/kindergarten

We are excited to offer this fun way to welcome Birmingham Public Schools newest students, no matter how they attend this fall. We‚Äôd also like to thank our sponsor DFCU Financial for helping to make this Welcome Kit possible!

A new American play by W.E. Groves High School alumnus Kenneth Jones (1982) makes its Groves debut in a live, socially-distanced staged reading outside the Groves High School auditorium from July 30 to Aug. 1 at 7:30 p.m.

A few tips if you plan on attending:
1. You will need to provide your own chair or blanket for seating.
2. The performance takes place outside under the stars in front of the Groves Auditorium doors.
3. Please plan on wearing your mask when you enter and when you move around.

post_text:
Today, the BPS Board of Education will meet to further discuss Restorative Practices and how they can be a vehicle to support the growth, development and academic success of all students.

Following the news article published on Tuesday, Board members began working to schedule this meeting in hopes of reviewing the matter and the ways in which the District could appropriately act. Our trustees understand the seriousness and gravity of the situation and their meeting today highlights their ongoing commitment to all of our students within the Birmingham Public Schools.

While the meeting will begin at 4 p.m. and can be viewed at www.youtube.com/birminghamps, the Board must move to a closed session to comply with all legal restrictions regarding student privacy. They will resume on Youtube following their discussion. The District will use Twitter and Facebook to share with the public when the Board will reconvene in live session.

Birmingham Public Schools staff and administrators have a deep commitment to working with each of our students to benefit their academic and personal growth. The concepts of diversity, equity and inclusion have been foundations of the school district‚Äôs work and will continue to provide a foundation for our school improvement in the future.

Birmingham Public Schools stands by its commitment that no child within our District should face consequences for lack of participation, incomplete assignments or missed work due to the sudden and required online continuity of learning plans that took place this past school year due to the global pandemic of COVID-19. The contest encourages residents to offer creative ways of sending the message that practices such as wearing face masks or social distancing continue to be critical components of fighting the #COVID19 pandemic. The contest is open to original artwork submitted by the original creator

column1: The contest has two ages divisions: 10-17 and 18 and above; and video or visual arts/2D categories for each. There is no limit to the number of times a person may enter but each entry must be done separately. Entry deadline is July 20th at 11:59 p.m.
The contest is only open to residents of Oakland County. A complete list of rules and details on how to enter the contest are found at www.oakgov.com/covid/contests."
image:
Oakland County, Michigan Government
July 7 at 9:35 PM ¬∑

#OaklandCounty is looking for residents of nearly any age who have an artistic flair or video-making chops to create original art or a video for #OaklandTogether COVID-19 Safety Video & Art Contest. Read more in our press release: http://ow.ly/kJ7W50Asies.

The contest encourages residents to offer creative ways of sending the message that practices such as wearing face masks or social distancing continue to be critical components of fighting the #COVID19 pandemic. The contest is open to original artwork submitted by the original creator, including but not limited to video, painting, drawing, photography, illustration and printmaking.

The contest has two ages divisions: 10-17 and 18 and above; and video or visual arts/2D categories for each. There is no limit to the number of times a person may enter but each entry must be done separately. Entry deadline is July 20th at 11:59 p.m.

The contest is only open to residents of Oakland County. A complete list of rules and details on how to enter the contest are found at www.oakgov.com/covid/contests.

July 13-24 (2 weeks)
Monday-Friday

post_text: Tonight, our BPS Board of Education passed a resolution that spoke to the role our District has in serving our Black and other historically marginalized students and families, as well as our commitment to serving the whole child as we partner with families in education. Our work to foster understanding, acceptance, and inclusion in this District has been ongoing, and the passage of this resolution shares our Board‚Äôs support and partnership in the work to combat racism within our schools and underscores our ongoing commitment to our students. Read the resolution here: https://www.birmingham.k12.mi.us/cms/lib/MI01908619/Centricity/Domain/67/ErradicateRacismBPSBoardResolution.pdf

Congratulations, Katie!

Tom Carson, Groves‚Äô first basketball coach, died suddenly of a heart attack following a basketball game in 1968. Every year since his death, the Tom Carson Memorial Award has been presented during graduation ceremonies to senior students who best personify the qualities of personal behavior which Mr. Carson taught and believed in. He encouraged students to be law-abiding, honest, sincere, show concern for others, and be loyal to family, friends, school and the community.

link:
Tom Carson, Groves‚Äô first basketball coach, died suddenly of a heart attack following a basketball game in 1968. Every year since his death, the Tom Carson Memorial Award has been presented during graduation ceremonies to senior students who best personify the qualities of personal behavior which Mr. Carson taught and believed in. He encouraged students to be law-abiding, honest, sincere, show concern for others, and be loyal to family, friends, school and the community.

This award is made possible through the Tom Carson Memorial Award Fund which is maintained by the Groves PTSA Boosters organization. A committee of students, parents, and faculty carefully review all nominations received and select the winners.

The recipients of the Groves High School 2020 Tom Carson Award are: Kyla Hurns, Kate Lucken and Nolan Kamoo.

Congratulations to our Tom Carson Award winners!

Today's Senior Spotlight is Morghan Christi Larson! Morghan was a member of Oakland Youth Orchestra for 7 years and was accepted to the National Society of High School Scholars in 2019. She will be attending Wittenburg University in the fall.

"In the future and especially in college, I want to learn how to draw better. I have a lot of ideas I want to work on, but I want to gain the skills to more easily translate that into tangible artworks. Eventually, I want to be able to draw quickly and accurately enough to make 2D animations, similar to anime."

Congratulations, Morghan!

Join Birmingham Covington School principal Mark Morawski, teachers Elizabeth Cook and Chris Emmi and BCS parent and Southfield Public Schools teacher, Nicole Jones, along with BCS students Julia T and Karsten P, as they consider these questions in "Cultivating Care in Times of Coronavirus" on May 27 from 7-8pm.

post_text:
Today we honor our military men and women who gave their lives for our country. While we know there are others from BPS that are among these heroes, today we‚Äôd like to share a little about Sgt. Michael Kashkoush. Sgt. Kashkoush attended Pembroke and Derby before moving to Ohio and serving as a counter intelligence/human intelligence specialist attached to the 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, 2nd Marine Division. He died on January 23, 2007 from wounds received while conducting combat operations near Fallujah in the Anbar Province of Iraq.

This Memorial Day, our deep thanks and respect is shared with Sgt. Kashkoush, his family and all of the military men and women who died while serving our country.

Today's Senior Spotlight is Paige Tait! Paige participated in band and tennis while at Seaholm. She will be attending the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and will be be majoring in Biology on a Pre-Med track.

"I am thankful for how challenging Seaholm was and the variety of classes that were offered. My favorite class was Parenting and Child Development because I was able to learn about genetics and the development of a child, which I plan to study in the future."

Congratulations, Paige!

post_text:
Today's Senior Spotlight is Tyler Austin! Tyler was a member of the swim team and LINKS. In the fall he will join the U.S. Paralympic Resident Swim Team at the National Training Center in Colorado Springs.

"Thank you to Dr. Roberson, Miss Murphy, Mrs. Rivera, Mr. Stuckey, Mr. Hurns, Mrs. Stuckey, and Mrs. Kelmigian for pushing me to work hard.

A special shout out to Miss McCain for supporting me in the classroom and also coming to my swim meets and baseball games. Thanks to Mr. Forrest for coaching me at the U.S. Paralympic Meet where I qualified for the National Team in the 100 Breaststroke.

I am so excited to live and train at the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Training Center with our nation's best athletes of all abilities! Tokyo 2021 is on the clock!

My favorite highlights from Groves are Spirit Week, the formal dress-up dances, and qualifying for MHSAA states"

Congratulations, Tyler!
text:
Today's Senior Spotlight is Tyler Austin! Tyler was a member of the swim team and LINKS. In the fall he will join the U.S. Paralympic Resident Swim Team at the National Training Center in Colorado Springs.

"Thank you to Dr. Roberson, Miss Murphy, Mrs. Rivera, Mr. Stuckey, Mr. Hurns, Mrs. Stuckey, and Mrs. Kelmigian for pushing me to work hard.

A special shout out to Miss McCain for supporting me in the classroom and also coming to my swim meets and baseball games. Thanks to Mr. Forrest for coaching me at the U.S. Paralympic Meet where I qualified for the National Team in the 100 Breaststroke.

I am so excited to live and train at the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Training Center with our nation's best athletes of all abilities! Tokyo 2021 is on the clock!

My favorite highlights from Groves are Spirit Week, the formal dress-up dances, and qualifying for MHSAA states"

Congratulations, Tyler!

Today's Senior Spotlight is Andrew Pflieger! Andrew is a member of the Seaholm Marching Band, Jazz Band, Symphony Band, and Orchestra Pit for Musicals. He also acted in Fall Play from 2016-2019. In the fall, he will be attending WMU double majoring in Music Education and Music Performance.
>>>>>>> master

"Starting Seaholm High School from a very small private school was intimidating. The teachers, administration, students, and especially the band program made me feel very comfortable. I didn‚Äôt just survive high school, I thrived.

These have been the best years of my life. I‚Äôve made friendships that will last a lifetime. All of my teachers have made a positive impact on my life, but none more than Mr Cibor. Having a common passion for music and seeing how he inspires his students has led me to pursue music education and performance."

Congratulations, Andrew!
text:
Today's Senior Spotlight is Andrew Pflieger! Andrew is a member of the Seaholm Marching Band, Jazz Band, Symphony Band, and Orchestra Pit for Musicals. He also acted in Fall Play from 2016-2019. In the fall, he will be attending WMU double majoring in Music Education and Music Performance.

"Starting Seaholm High School from a very small private school was intimidating. The teachers, administration, students, and especially the band program made me feel very comfortable. I didn‚Äôt just survive high school, I thrived.

These have been the best years of my life. I‚Äôve made friendships that will last a lifetime. All of my teachers have made a positive impact on my life, but none more than Mr Cibor. Having a common passion for music and seeing how he inspires his students has led me to pursue music education and performance."

Congratulations, Andrew!

"I am grateful for the way Seaholm has equipped and enabled me to pursue my interests"

Congratulations, Bennett!

Birmingham Community Education has added Skyhawks Sports Academy classes to their virtual class offerings to keep our community active and healthy while at home. The weekly class schedule will serve ages 3-12 years and will include offerings from SuperTots, Skyhawks, and STEM Sports, as well as fundamental movement and physical education.

Visit the Birmingham Community Education homepage at www.communityed.net for more information and to register.

post_text:
Congratulations to Birmingham‚Äôs FIRST Robotics Team, Automation Nation for winning the Chairman‚Äôs Award at the FIRST Robotics Detroit District tournament.

The Chairman's Award is the most prestigious award in the FIRST Robotics Competition. It recognizes a team that reflects sustained excellence and impact within the FIRST community, in its own community, and beyond.

post_text:
Groves junior Isaiah Rubin started a community service project, Caring Cards for COVID-19. So far, he has safely delivered more than 350 cards for distribution to patients at various senior centers in Oakland County. Now, Isaiah is calling on fellow students to support the project by making handmade cards for patients and seniors. The cards can be placed in a new drop box located outside the front entrance to Groves.

Groves junior Isaiah Rubin started a community service project, Caring Cards for COVID-19. So far, he has safely delivered more than 350 cards for distribution to patients at various senior centers in Oakland County. Now, Isaiah is calling on fellow students to support the project by making handmade cards for patients and seniors. The cards can be placed in a new drop box located outside the front entrance to Groves.

Read more about the project here:
https://thejewishnews.com/2020/04/15/teenager-spearheads-initiative-to-get-hand-made-cards-to-lonely-patients-seniors/

Did you know that one of Berkshire‚Äôs 3D printers has been printing face shields around the clock for use in local hospitals? Absolutely amazing!!!

post_text:
Breakfast and lunch will be continued through April 13, Monday-Friday. Children 18 and younger eat free and children do not need to be present or enrolled in BPS to receive the meals. Additionally, students from the BPS Annex site up to age 26 also have access to the free breakfast and lunch services.

Pick up locations include Groves High School in Beverly Hills, Derby Middle School in Birmingham, West Maple in Bloomfield Hills and Huntley Square Apartments in Beverly Hills.

shared_text:
Next - Your Place to Stay Active and Connected
March 16 at 5:28 PM ¬∑

Next will continue to support our members and the community but unfortunately we will be suspending all activities until further notice due to the corona virus.

Next is increasing our outreach for our members and community residents. If you, or someone you know,
has a need we can assist with, please call our main office number 248.203.5270. Our staff hours will be reduced but we will be answering phones and returning and voicemails. The Next building will be open for limited services, please call ahead to verify availability.

Meals on Wheels and the SMART Transportation will operate as normal. We will continue to monitor the situation and communicate accordingly.

Many of our members live alone, but please remember Next is family and you are not without support. Call us with any social, emotional or health related concerns; we are here, and will remain here, to assist you.

post_text:
Detroit Public TV, in partnership with community educators and in collaboration with PBS stations across Michigan, will be providing educational programming and associated digital resources that adhere to Michigan‚Äôs state curriculum to foster at-home learning across all grade levels.

The Detroit PBS KIDS Channel (56.2) is available 24 hours a day seven days a week with kids‚Äô favorite shows ‚Äì Daniel Tiger‚Äôs Neighborhood, Arthur, Pinkalicious and Peterrific, Wild Kratts, Odd Squad, and many others. The programming also can be accessed on the Detroit PBS KIDS website and on the PBS KIDS app, available for free on a wide range of platforms.

Detroit Public TV will also be providing daily communications with suggestions for content, activities and learning opportunities through newsletters and social media, as well as at DPTV.org and DetroitPBSKIDS.org.

We wanted to provide some essential information for staff and families today and have sent a detailed email that we are asking everyone to review. We realize this is a lot of information, but wanted to provide a single-source document for your reference. This message will be posted on our website, along with other resources and documents, at www.birmingham.k12.mi.us/covid19.

Thank you again for your continued patience and flexibility during this unprecedented time. Stay well, take care of one another, and look for continued updates from us in the coming days and weeks!

Message emailed to families a few moments ago:

We wanted to provide an update this morning following our message last night. Know that we are developing plans to deliver a temporary, online alternative for students during this extended closure. We will communicate more about those plans by Monday evening.

In preparation for that work, our middle and high school buildings will be open from 12-3 p.m. and our elementary schools, BCS and Early Childhood Center will be open from 12-4 p.m. for students to pick up their belongings and any personal supplies, if needed. Items picked up should be limited to personal items only and we expect students and families to be respectful of our buildings and‚Ä¶ More

post_text:
Today is Election Day! We wanted to remind you that your voice counts and we hope you'll take time to head to the polls. Birmingham Public Schools will have a Bond Proposal on the ballot which seeks voter consideration. The bond proposal seeks to keep general fund dollars focused on the classroom while dedicating bond funds to vital capital needs throughout the District.

post_id:
Today is Election Day! We wanted to remind you that your voice counts and we hope you'll take time to head to the polls. Birmingham Public Schools will have a Bond Proposal on the ballot which seeks voter consideration. The bond proposal seeks to keep general fund dollars focused on the classroom while dedicating bond funds to vital capital needs throughout the District.

To learn more about the proposal, visit our website at www.birmingham.k12.mi.us/bond2020. Polls will be open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Visit www.vote.org to learn where to vote or how to register.

post_text: Yesterday, the Groves Choir traveled to Clarenceville High School to participate in the MSVMA Choral Festival. They performed two songs for a panel of adjudicators and then participated in sight-reading a page of songs they had never seen before. They earned a first division rating, qualifying them to perform at the state level of Choral Festival!

Contact Dylan Brown to arrange a drop off anytime in March at (248) 303-9937 or dkb303@icloud.com.

post_text: The documentary Baggage: my story will be shown on Friday, March 13 at 6:30 p.m. in the Groves Auditorium. The documentary gives voice to young immigrants aged 12 to 17, newly arrived in Montreal. The free viewing will be followed by a Q & A with the M√©lissa LeFebvre, the Drama teacher from the documentary, Simon Boulerice, an author and Language Arts teacher who published a book containing poetry by the students, and Deborah Drennen, the CEO of Freedom House. Recommended for ages 10 and up. Visit www.cariboualunettes.com/events for more information and to view the trailer.

The free viewing will be followed by a Q & A with the M√©lissa LeFebvre, the Drama teacher from the documentary, Simon Boulerice, an author and Language Arts teacher who published a book containing poetry by the students, and Deborah Drennen, the CEO of Freedom House. Recommended for ages 10 and up. Visit www.cariboualunettes.com/events for more information and to view the trailer.

Two Student Contests Celebrating Women‚Äôs Suffrage ‚Äì Oakland Schools Education Foundation

Oakland County Board of Commissioners
February 26 at 6:00 PM ¬∑

The deadline for the poetry and PSA contests is less than a month away! The Board, in partnership with Oakland Schools - Michigan is hosting a poetry and PSA contest in celebration of the 100th Anniversary of Women's Suffrage! The poetry contest is open to all K-12 students enrolled at an #OaklandCounty school. The PSA contest is open to Oakland County students in grades 6-12. Cash prizes will be awarded courtesy of Cornerstone Community Financial Credit Union. The submission deadline for both contests is Friday, 3/20. For more information, visit http://bit.ly/2vP8mUQ.

post_text:
In one week, voters will be asked to consider a bond proposal for Birmingham Public Schools. The bond proposal seeks to keep general fund dollars focused on the classrooms while dedicating bond funds to vital capital needs throughout the District. If approved, the annual debt millage is expected to remain at or below the annual debt millage of 3.80 mills levied in 2019. Visit https://mvic.sos.state.mi.us/ for polling locations and registration information.

In one week, voters will be asked to consider a bond proposal for Birmingham Public Schools. The bond proposal seeks to keep general fund dollars focused on the classrooms while dedicating bond funds to vital capital needs throughout the District. If approved, the annual debt millage is expected to remain at or below the annual debt millage of 3.80 mills levied in 2019. Visit https://mvic.sos.state.mi.us/ for polling locations and registration information.

Learn more about the bond proposal at https://www.birmingham.k12.mi.us/bond2020.

link:
Stay informed about the Coronavirus Disease 2019 from trusted sources such as the Center for Disease Control at www.cdc.gov/coronavirus. Prevent the spread of the Coronavirus with the same preventative measures used for the flu. The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services advises the following steps can be taken to prevent spread of flu and the common cold that will also help prevent Coronavirus disease, including:

¬∑ Washing your hands with soap and water.
¬∑ Avoiding touching your eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands.
¬∑ Covering your mouth and nose with a tissue or upper sleeve when coughing or sneezing.
¬∑ Avoiding contact with people who are sick.
¬∑ Staying home if you are sick and contact your healthcare provider.

post_text: Groves Student Congress is hosting their first ever community Charity Week blood drive, on Saturday March 28 from 9 a.m. to 2:50p.m. at Groves High School. Use this link to sign up for a time slot that works best for you. If you have any questions about donor eligibility, visit www.versiti.org or call Versiti Blood Center of Michigan at 866-642-5663 : The following are examples of guidelines used to determine if a donor is eligible to donate blood. The whole donation process would take about an hour of your time. If you have any questions or would like to sign up differently, you can email Katie Lucken at katielucken@gmail.com

>>>>>>> master
February 28 at 11:50 PM ¬∑

Miss Michigan 2020, Chanel Johnson was our guest today as we celebrated Black History month at Greenfield. She shared a message about the importance of positive behavior, community service, finding what makes you unique and look to your parents, teachers and other adults in your life for guidance. Thank you for sharing your experiences and we loved that our homegrown Greenfield, Berkshire and Groves graduate came to share her message with us today! Birmingham Public Schools Greenfield Pta

post_text: Birmingham Unified Hockey raised over $5,000 for the Apap Foundation in honor of Paul Apap, a long time youth hockey supporter and Birmingham Hockey Association coach who passed away from ALS in December. The proceeds from the charity games will help families defray the costs of helping patients living with ALS.
text: Birmingham Unified Hockey raised over $5,000 for the Apap Foundation in honor of Paul Apap, a long time youth hockey supporter and Birmingham Hockey Association coach who passed away from ALS in December. The proceeds from the charity games will help families defray the costs of helping patients living with ALS.

post_text:
Seaholm students volunteered at John Dingell Veterans Hospital on February 10 and 13, during National Salute to Veteran Patients Week. Students engaged with veterans in a variety of activities, from helping with intake, transporting patients, and playing games, to passing out Valentines and giving out hats and gloves. Students left feeling inspired and motivated by the stories of service they heard and want to do more for Veterans in the future.
.

Students left feeling inspired and motivated by the stories of service they heard and want to do more for Veterans in the future.

post_text:
Seaholm students volunteered at John Dingell Veterans Hospital on February 10 and 13, during National Salute to Veteran Patients Week. Students engaged with veterans in a variety of activities, from helping with intake, transporting patients, and playing games, to passing out Valentines and giving out hats and gloves. Students left feeling inspired and motivated by the stories of service they heard and want to do more for Veterans in the future.
.
text:
Seaholm students volunteered at John Dingell Veterans Hospital on February 10 and 13, during National Salute to Veteran Patients Week. Students engaged with veterans in a variety of activities, from helping with intake, transporting patients, and playing games, to passing out Valentines and giving out hats and gloves. Students left feeling inspired and motivated by the stories of service they heard and want to do more for Veterans in the future.

This is a full-day preschool, M-Th, 8:30-3:30, and located at Bingham Farms Elementary.

link:
‚ÄúCooking‚Äù up the fun in a preschool sensory table! Sensory play:

- Builds nerve connections within the developing brain‚Äôs neural pathways, which trigger a child‚Äôs inclination for and ability in competing more complex learning tasks
- Supports language development, cognitive growth, motor skills, problem solving skills, and social interaction
- Aids in developing and enhancing memory functioning
- Great for calming an anxious or frustrated child
- Helps children learn vitally important sensory attributes (hot, cold, sticky, dry, etc)

The learning possibilities are endless at a BPS Early Learning program. Call 248-203-5805 to learn more about our high-quality early childhood programs and the many options available. #BPSLearners

post_text: BCS sixth-grader Charlisa Penzak won the Oakland County "I Voted!" sticker contest! Congratulations, Charlisa!
shared_text:
Oakland Schools - Michigan
>>>>>>> master
November 21, 2019 at 2:15 PM ¬∑

Yesterday evening, the Oakland County Board of Commissioners announced the winners of Oakland County‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Voted!‚Äù sticker contest. Winners Penelope Blanchard (9th grade) from Walled Lake Western High School and Charlisa Penzak (6th grade) from Birmingham Covington School will have their designs printed as ‚ÄòI Voted!‚Äô stickers, which will be distributed to voters at precincts throughout the county in 2020. Both students received a $1,000 prize courtesy of Cornerstone Community Financial Credit Union. More than 600 middle and high school students across Oakland County submitted entries.

Photo credit: Derek Cookson

post_text:
Due to ongoing weather conditions, Birmingham Public Schools will release middle and high school students early to maintain a normal release for our elementary school students.
‚Ä¢ High school students will release at 1:30 p.m.
‚Ä¢ Middle school (Derby and Berkshire) students will release at 2:15 p.m.
‚Ä¢ Elementary school will release at 3:50 (normal release). Please note that students may arrive home later than normal as we work to safely drop students off.
‚Ä¢ BCS will release at the normal time.

No after school activities for elementary and middle school students (and BCS). High school activities will be communicated from individual buildings. Community Education activities will continue as planned.

Parents of Kids Club students, Kids Club closes at 6:00 p.m. As the traffic can get unpredictable with winter weather, please plan your commute accordingly. Early pick-up when possible is appreciated by Kids Club staff members.

What a wonderful moment to share! Thank you to the anonymous donor! We‚Äôre grateful to have teachers like Mr. Fink making a positive impact every day! Thank you Birmingham Education Foundation!

Birmingham Education Foundation is feeling fantastic.
November 8, 2019 at 7:32 PM ¬∑

Today, thanks to an anonymous donor, we surprised Wylie E Groves - Home of the Falcons Art Teacher Mr. Fink with the news that he would be receiving $3,500 to support his classes! The donor said they were moved to give after seeing the impact Mr. Fink has on his students. We want to say a very special thank you to the donor for this gift and for making this moment possible. Enjoy these photos of Mr. Fink learning about the donation!

post_text: The Birmingham Early Childhood Center is looking for nurturing individuals to work as full-time assistant teachers in a toddler or preschool classroom. The starting hourly rate, depending on qualifications, is $11.32 with the opportunity for benefits and paid leave. Be sure to share this flyer with anyone you think would be a great addition to the BPS community!

post_text: We love the work the The Birmingham Museum has done to help preserve and share our history. Thank you!!
shared_text:
CANDGNEWS.COM
Looking Back: The Hill School, 1914

The Birmingham Museum
November 3, 2019 at 4:47 PM ¬∑

On this date in 1969, Birmingham's Hill School was torn down. Constructed in 1869 and first called Union School, it provided free secondary education to Birmingham's students for the first time. To learn more about this school, check out a previous "Looking Back" article and our virtual exhibit about Birmingham's early schools.
https://www.candgnews.com/news/looking-back-hill-school-1914-91136
https://www.bhamgov.org/history/museum/early_school_history.php

post_text:
Getting to know Hispanic and Latino/A/X persons in our community
A Panel Discussion
Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2019 6:00-8:00 p.m.
BCS Media Center
Join panelists as they share their personal experiences as they relate to being Hispanic & Latino/a/x within our community. A family and community event with a diverse panel of speakers, including students, parents and BPS staff. Birmingham Covington School, Media Center on Tuesday, Oct. 15 from 6:00-8:00 p.m. Enjoy cultural foods from 6:00 - 6:30 p.m. Panel begins at 6:30 p.m. All are welcome.https://drive.google.com/file/d/1O1xkTExUW5c0UjTotH_advWGRo06oliQ/view

A family and community event with a diverse panel of speakers, including students, parents and BPS staff. Birmingham Covington School, Media Center on Tuesday, Oct. 15 from 6:00-8:00 p.m. Enjoy cultural foods from 6:00 - 6:30 p.m. Panel begins at 6:30 p.m. All are welcome.https://drive.google.com/file/d/1O1xkTExUW5c0UjTotH_advWGRo06oliQ/view

post_text: Congratulations Greenfield Gators!!
shared_text:
Birmingham Education Foundation
September 10, 2019 at 7:09 PM ¬∑

We are so proud to announce that the winner of the #BEFBackToSchool Shoefie Contest is Greenfield Elementary School! The smallest Birmingham Public Schools Elementary decided to Dream Big, and managed to collect a whopping 1,850 shoe-fies during the contest to win the $500 grant.

Thank you so much to everyone for participating in this fun challenge! Together, you posted more than 4,330 #BEFBackToSchool shoe-fies. If you were inspired by the spirit of our schools, we encourage you to make a gift to support the BEF Grant Program, which awards schools and teachers grants, allowing them to Dream Big for our kids. You can give online at https://www.supportbef.org/donate.

Last week, enthusiasm and VOTES from metro-Detroiters helped push the Detroit Youth Choir through to the semi-finals. Now the choir is just one step away from the FINALE! Watch and vote for the Detroit Youth Choir, Tuesday, September 10th at 8pm, on WDIV-Local 4.

post_text: BPS is hiring! Applications are being accepted for the position of Caregiver for the GSRP preschool program for Birmingham Public Schools, housed at Bingham Farms Elementary. GSRP is a full-day program for 4-year-olds. The caregiver will work with one other team member to support lunch and afternoon activities. This is a non-bargaining unit position. The hours are 11:00am-2:00pm, Monday-Thursday. Applicants, who want to be considered for this position, must submit a letter of interest emailed directly to Laura Tinsley, Principal of Early Learning, at LTinsley@birmingham.k12.mi.us.

post_text:
REGISTER NOW! Register your little one in a BPS Early Learning program today! Half day, full day, neighborhood locations, center-based offerings and GSRP available. Learn about all the options at www.birmingham.k12.mi.us/earlylearning or call 248.203.5805.

BPS Early Learning programs are committed to providing a nurturing and secure educational setting for young children and their families. In a safe, age-appropriate, engaging environment, children learn and explore as they experience their world. Our play-based programs encourage the development of each child's unique potential. The process enhances physical, emotional, social, creative and intellectual growth. Staff, children and families, in partnership with the community, learn to value diversity and to foster individuality, self-confidence, love of learning and respect for themselves and others.

Birmingham Summer Camp and Academic Review options still available this summer! www.communityed.net

Elementary Academic Review for grades K-5 runs July 22-August 9 (three weeks) from 9 a.m.- 12 p.m., M-F, at Birmingham Covington School. This class offers review and reinforcement of math and reading skills and is taught by BPS staff. Add an afternoon camp for an all-day experience!

Birmingham Community Education offers 20+ half day camps every week, including sports, cooking, fashion design, sculpture, computer game design, chess, kids empowered‚Ä¶and MORE! Open swim times and swim lessons also available.

Check out our weekly camp guide at www.communityed.net or call 248.203.3800 to register.

post_text: For the last two weeks, fourth grade students at West Maple have been writing their favorite authors to ask for translations of their books for our world languages library as part of a larger project. Already, three authors have responded and agreed to donate their books! Kudos to our fourth grade students, along with staff members Becky Gilbert, Carrie Betts, Kalyn Wulatin, Kevin Hall, Maria Broz, Bailee Balant and Josh Sammons!

text:
Join the Friends of Different Learners Thursday, June 6 at 7 p.m. for their regular meeting at Birmingham Covington School, 1525 Covington in Bloomfield Hills. The group will hold their wrap-up meeting for the year and plan for the 2019-20 school year.

More information about Friends, including Executive Members, Building Reps, and Local & National Resources can be found at www.friendsofdifferentlearners.org.

post_text:
Ms. Dishinger's fifth graders at Pembroke presented their Wax Museum as a culmination of their biography research projects this week. Students presented as if they were the person or as a museum docent. One student presented as George Patton, General of WWII, and was able to wear his great grandfather‚Äôs hat and uniform coat! A wonderful way to honor his great grandfather! Other features were Amelia Earhart, Florence Nightingale, Walt Disney, Milton Hershey, Wayne Gretzky, Harriet Tubman, Babe Ruth, J.K. Rowling and many more.
it was a great way to bring learning to life as many historical figures were presented!

link:
She certainly helped shape future generations!

The Birmingham Museum
May 10, 2019 at 2:00 PM ¬∑

On this date in 1915, the city of Birmingham passed an ordinance that accepted the terms of Martha Baldwin's will. Her will gave the city many things, among them money to build Baldwin High School and some of her land to create Baldwin Park. Baldwin had died two years earlier in 1913 at the age of 73.

image:
Congratulations to Automation Nation! Thank you Mr. Simms and Mr. Hoover! What an amazing year!

Ernest W. Seaholm High School
April 30, 2019 at 12:35 PM ¬∑

Congratulations to Birmingham‚Äôs Robotics team, Automation Nation. They competed at the FIRST Robotics World Championship, held at Cobo Hall and Ford Field in Detroit, MI, April 25-27. The team was in the Carson Division, where they compiled a record of 8 wins against only 2 losses, propelling them to 6th place out of 68 teams. For the elimination rounds, they moved up one more spot and were the 5th place alliance captain. Birmingham‚Äôs alliance won their quarterfinal matchup, advancing to the division semi-finals, where they lost to the number one seeded alliance. The world championship featured over 400 high school teams and over 10,000 students, elementary grades through high school. The team is led by teachers Bernie Simms and Pat Hoover. For more information about FIRST Robotics visit: https://www.firstinspires.org/
Birmingham Public Schools

post_text: ‚ÄúGetting to Know LGBTQ Persons in Our Community: A Panel Discussion‚Äù is a family and community event which will be held from 6:30-7:45 p.m. on Thursday May 2 at Birmingham Covington School in the library. Panelists include students from our two high schools; Ian Unger, the youth outreach coordinator from Affirmations; and parents from PFLAG Detroit. Please come and hear students and community members share stories from multiple perspectives as they relate to the LGBTQ community. Free and open to the public. Refreshments served.

post_text:
Friday and Saturday, May 3-4, 2019
Southeast Michigan STEM Summit
Calling all STEM educators, families, businesses and non-profits: The Southeast Michigan STEM Summit will take place at the Oakland Center at Oakland University May 3-4. Event highlights include keynote presentations by local, statewide and national STEM experts; breakout sessions for key audiences, including educators/administrators, students/parents, legislators, businesses and non-profits; STEM vendor exhibits; student STEM demonstrations. Register at www.connect.space/se-mi-stem-summit-2019

post_text: The Birmingham Robotics team, Automation Nation, comprised of students from Seaholm High School and Groves High School, qualified for the WORLD FIRST Robotics Championship, held at Cobo Hall and Ford Field in Detroit, MI. The team is advancing as a result of their performance at States, where they were awarded The Creativity Award sponsored by Xerox, due to the unique climbing mechanism. They reached the quarterfinal round in their division before getting eliminated. The Robotic team is led by Bernie Simms and Pat Hoover. https://www.firstchampionship.org/detroit

The team competed at the Troy District tournament March 29-30, and reached the Semi-finals before being eliminated by the 1st place team. Their sustained effort over two district tournaments qualified them into the field at MSC, which will be held at Saginaw State Valley State University April 11-13. For information about the State Championship visit https://svsu.edu/firstatsvsu/

GOING TO STATES! The Birmingham Robotics team, Automation Nation, comprised of students from Seaholm High School and Groves High School, qualified for the Michigan FIRST Robotics State Championship! The team competed at the Troy District tournament March 29-30, and reached the Semi-finals before being eliminated by the 1st place team. Their sustained effort over two district tournaments qualified them into the field at MSC, which will be held at Saginaw State Valley State University April 11-13. For information about the State Championship visit https://svsu.edu/firstatsvsu/

The Robotics team is led by Seaholm teachers Bernie Simms and Pat Hoover.

shared_text:
Thank you to all of our volunteers that helped make such an impact!

Birmingham Covington School
April 9, 2019 at 8:16 PM ¬∑

You may recall that last September 22, 2018, @BCS_Cobras hosted a district wide community service event ‚Äì a Kids Against Hunger packaging. Students and parents had the opportunity to pour, weigh, and package 256,000 Kids Against Hunger meals to feed children in need. The meals have arrived in Yemen, and here are pictures of families receiving the food items we packaged. Thank you to our great community for supporting this service opportunity and Kimber Bishop-Yanke for coordinating!

post_text: The Latino Family Network is celebrating their first anniversary! LAFAN has focused on fostering educational excellence and equity, improving language fluency (Spanish and Portuguese) and celebrating family traditions and values. In partnership with Birmingham Community Education, LAFAN worked to create advanced Spanish classes for K-8 BPS students through a Saturday Immersion Class. To learn more about the classes or how to get involved with LAFAN, email bpslafan@gmail.com.

post_text: Seaholm is pleased to announce their 2019 Carson Scholar, Leah Kim. The Carson Scholars Fund awards college scholarships to students in grades 4 through 11 who excel academically and are dedicated to serving their communities. Across the nation, only 505 students are receiving the designation of 2019 Carson Scholars. An interested student must be nominated by his/her school to be able to compete for a Carson Scholar. The minimum requirements are a 3.75 GPA and involvement in community service. Congratulations Leah!

post_text:
District calendar update!!
While we work to finalize the Birmingham Public Schools 2019-20 school year calendar, we would like to share with you our start and end dates along with scheduled breaks for the upcoming school year. We will share the calendar in full once it has been finalized and approved.

2019-20 Break Schedule
Tuesday, Sept. 3, 2019 ‚Äì First day of school (Half Day, AM only)
Sept. 26 ‚Äì All Schools half day (AM only)
Nov. 27-29 ‚Äì Thanksgiving Recess
Dec. 23-Jan. 1 ‚Äì Winter Recess
Jan. 20 ‚Äì No School (MLK Day)
Feb. 14 ‚Äì All Schools half day (AM only)
Feb. 17-21 ‚Äì Midwinter Recess
April 6-10 ‚Äì Spring Recess
April 24 ‚Äì All Schools half day (AM only)
May 25 ‚Äì No School (Memorial Day)
Friday, June 12 ‚Äì Last day of school

Proud of our global Derby Dragons at home and away!

Derby Middle School
March 24, 2019 at 4:32 PM ¬∑

We are so proud of our global Derby learners! This week we were spread around the globe in both China and Costa Rica!

post_text: This week our Superintendent had the chance to read to BPS Wee Care students as we celebrate March is Reading Month. Thank you to Wee Care's Director Danielle Mitchelson for organizing the visit with Mr. Dziatczak!
